docs.lead_paragraph: Far from the center of New York's literary hub, in a flat-topped industrial building fringed by Florida palms and flaming pink hibiscus, is a publisher that produces hot books in a bouillon of chicken soup flavors. There is little about the publisher, Health Communications, that is conventional except that it ladles up best sellers: three currently on the New York Times paperback best-seller lists last weekend, including ''Chicken Soup for the Teenage Soul,'' the 17th book in its warm, shivery and carefully formatted Chicken Soup series of simplistic and homespun inspirational parables of love, kindness and triumph.

headline.main: Breaking the Publishing Mold; A New Book Empire Your Mother Would Love

docs.abstract: Profile of Health Communiations, Deerfield Beach, Florida, publisher of hot books; Health Communications currently has three best sellers on New York Times paperback best-seller lists, including Chicken Soup for the Teenage Soul, 17th book in its warm, shivery and carefully formatted Chicken Soup series of simplistic and homespun inspirational parables of love, kindness and triumph; interview with Peter Vegso, co-founder and pres of Health Communications; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The hot United States economy is showing signs of cooling, but by only a few degrees. In June, the Labor Department reported yesterday, unemployment edged up to 4.5 percent and job growth slowed. There were other signs of moderation. Total hours worked were virtually flat in June, a clear indication that the nation's output of goods and services is growing much more slowly than in recent quarters. And hourly pay rose by a mere penny, suggesting that wage inflation, while higher than a year ago, was not accelerating.

headline.main: June Job Data Show Growth Eased a Little

docs.abstract: Hot United States economy is shows signs of cooling, but by only a few degrees; Labor Dept reports that unemployment edged up to 4.5 percent in June; there are other signs of moderation; total hours worked are virtually flat in June, clear indication that nation's output of goods and services is growing much more slowly than in recent quarters; hourly pay rises by mere penny, suggesting that wage inflation, while higher than year ago, is not accelerating; slowdown, however, is from exceptionaly torrid pace; payrolls grew by 205,000 last month, compared with more than 300,000 in each of two previous months; graphics (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your June 28 front-page article depicts physicians at the bottom of the food chain but does not explain why. Doctors have hurt themselves through isolated private practices, inability to respond to structural changes in medicine, and a delay in developing a collective business mentality.
docs.abstract: Dr Sunil S Jhangiani letter disputes June 28 article on tightening of rules by health insurers, reducing fees paid to doctors; says article depicts doctors at bottom of food chain but fails to explain why (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your June 28 front-page article and June 29 editorial ''Warming Up to Patients' Rights'' show how employers are distorting the American health care system. As you report, health insurers are responding to employers' demands to contain premium increases by cutting physicians' fees. Employers are clueless about what the correct price should be, yet proclaim that it must be level or lower and continue to transform the health care system in ways that consumers hate.
docs.abstract: Dwight McNeill letter says June 28 article and June 29 editorial on health insurance and patients' rights show how employers are distorting American health care system (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Insurers Tighten Rules and Reduce Fees for Doctors'' (front page, June 28): Health maintenance organizations conveniently overlook the fact that physicians are the key value creators in the health care system. Thus I find the arbitrary fee reductions that health insurers are imposing by fiat on physicians to be particularly galling.
docs.abstract: Dr Jay S Markowitz letter, commenting on June 28 article on tightening of rules by health insurers reducing fees for doctors, says insurers conveniently overlook fact that doctors are key value creators in health care system (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: TEMPTING as it may seem, Dan Cavaluzzi, a towboat captain, does not refer to the weekend sailors who get hung up on sandbars or run out of fuel as jerks, morons or any of the other terms one may use for people who mess up because of their own incompetence. Anyone can make a mistake, says Captain Cavaluzzi, who works for TowBoat/U.S., a sort of A.A.A. for boaters. It is not his job to be ''judgmental.'' What's the point of asking why an $85,000, 35-foot cabin cruiser ended up roosting on pilings in the Hudson River, making, when the tide is out, for a remarkable photo that is one of the first things the captain shows to a visitor?

headline.main: Belying the Legend of the Crusty Old Salt

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Warming Up to Patients' Rights'' (editorial, June 29): We agree that the Republican leadership inserted some poison pills into its patient protection plan. Although the American Medical Association has long supported medical malpractice limits on pain and suffering awards as well as medical savings accounts, we do not support their inclusion in any patient protection legislation. We will fight that battle on another day.
docs.abstract: Letter from American Medical Assn chairman Dr Randolph D Smoak, commenting on June 29 editorial on patients' rights, opposes provisions in patient protection bill advanced by House Republican leadership that would place limits on medical malpractice awards and establish medical savings accounts; drawing (S)
